title: 'The sharps or flats always appear in the same order in all key signatures. This is the same order in which they are added as keys get sharper or flatter.' What does this mean? - Quora

response.answer_text: Some music theory teachers may teach you the scales "in order" - ie C major/C minor, D major/D minor, E major/E minor, etc. However, I think one of the more effective techniques is to learn the scales in the order of how many sharps/flats occur in the scale - ie no sharps, 1 sharp, 2 sharps, 3 sharps, etc., no flats, 1 flat, 2 flats, 3 flats, etc. So you end up with something like this:  Which is exponentially easier to learn and remember. Notice anything interesting?  A whole lot of stuff should start jumping out at you, and you’ll start noticing a WHOLE LOT of different patterns going on. There’s at least 10 more going on. Good luck!

Sharps and flats always appear in the same order: Sharps: FCGDAEB The first key with one sharp, F#, is G major. D major adds a sharp, C#, and so on. So when you get to A major, you’ll have three sharps F C G. Flats: BEADGCF (you’ll notice it’s the sharps reversed) F has one flat, Bb. The next key that adds Eb to the existing Bb is Bb Major. I must admit, the quoted text is rather poorly written, I assume from a textbook. “Sharper or flatter” is the dumbest thing I’ve ever heard applied to the concept of key signatures.
